stream_context.summary: Kaze works on the papercraft-desert opening level of Return to Yoshi’s Island, tweaking Mario’s spin-jump, planning Yoshi-coin challenges, building a cardboard Bowser encounter, and prototyping a new “thimble Shy Guy” enemy while testing performance and shader tricks on real N64 hardware.

development_findings.summary: Spin-jump re-balanced: lower initial lift, extra height tied to A-button mashing, slower turn rate, minimal horizontal drift so it becomes a ‘safety stall’ rather than a skip-everything move.
development_findings.quote: I made it so that the initial velocity is less, but mashing A gives you more height. It’s kind of nice that each individual A-press is emphasized.

development_findings.summary: Yoshi-coin design framework: each coin tied to a small bespoke interaction (NPC task, hidden path, set-piece). Current ideas include a trampoline launch, hidden cardboard flap entrance, Peach-rescue from Shy Guys, cardboard Bowser bridge, and a Pink Bob-omb cannon.
development_findings.quote: The Yoshi coins are special interactions; this level doesn’t have many NPCs, so we need to get creative.

development_findings.summary: Prototype ‘thimble Shy Guy’ enemy built: metal thimble body with hand-drawn mask, textured bumps to fake metal dimples. Will spawn in groups harassing a Peach doodle; defeating them awards a Yoshi coin.
Cardboard Bowser cut-out encounter sketched: simple SMB1-style bridge of cardboard boxes, Bowser shoots fire, guarding a Yoshi coin—no full boss collapse coded.
development_findings.quote: We just want a small interaction. Bowser would be a cutout that shoots fire at you.

development_findings.summary: Stylised shader breakthrough: Kaze implements camera-space normal/specular trick to fake shiny Styrofoam/metal on N64, debates terminology (normal vs specular vs bump map).
development_findings.quote: I found out that what I wanted wasn’t actually a normal map…but it is the thing I have now.

development_findings.summary: Performance test: 7,500 triangles of actual geometry (88k with text) run smoothly on real N64; custom engine keeps 30 FPS target.
development_findings.quote: This is the 8,000-polygon level we did not optimise yet, and the framerate is not completely atrocious.

development_findings.summary: Cloud props replaced: switches from placeholder cotton balls to lower-poly sculpted clouds supplied by contributors for visual clarity and polygon budget.
Considering converting oasis to paper waterfall using reflective strips but unsure about collision/interaction code.
development_findings.quote: Whatever we do, we either have to program something that moves out of the way or it’s going to be solid – neither solves the issue.

context_findings.summary: Kaze prioritises accessibility over speed-runner exploits—won’t change mechanics purely to preserve advanced tricks.
context_findings.quote: I’m not making changes just so you can back-a-muse. If you can, great; I won’t cater to that.

context_findings.summary: Project will remain free; legal constraints prevent monetisation, though he'd consider cosmetic DLC if allowed.
context_findings.quote: I never charge for my games – I wouldn’t be allowed to. If I was, maybe I’d release the base game for free and sell a skin.

context_findings.summary: Acknowledges first persistent ‘hater’ disliking uploads; handles it humorously.
context_findings.quote: There’s one person disliking every video two minutes after upload – this is exciting.

biobak.summary: Provided new cloud model (69 triangles) and has nearly finished a ‘dummy’ asset; also replaced outdated enemy textures.

badub.summary: Will compose music that changes by biome within the level; Kaze waiting on his draft.
badub.quote: I’m going to see what music Badub comes up with; ideally it changes depending on which biome you’re in.

zeina.summary: Working on cloud artwork and general animations; requests to draw clouds rather than use 3-D cotton balls.
zeina.quote: Zeina wants to draw in clouds anyway, so I’m attaching them right now.

key_stories.title: Taming the Overpowered Spin-Jump
key_stories.summary: Early tests showed the Smash-style spin-jump let players scale walls and break level design. Kaze methodically cut its upward force, added mash-based height, and limited horizontal control until it felt like a mid-air safety tool, not a skip button.
key_stories.challenge: Spin-jump trivialised platforming and vertical limits.
key_stories.process: Reduced initial velocity, increased per-press boost, capped turning and speed, live-tested in level.
key_stories.outcome: Move now stalls more than ascends; Kaze deems it ‘fine the way it is’ for current builds.
key_stories.key_quote: It gives you a feeling of security when it’s available to you, but you kind of do not want to use it.

key_stories.title: Inventing the Thimble Shy Guy
key_stories.summary: Needing more craft-themed enemies for Yoshi-coin tasks, the chat brainstormed object options. Kaze settled on a metal thimble with a hand-drawn mask and textured dimples, saving polygons while reading instantly as a Shy Guy.
key_stories.challenge: Create a recognisable Shy Guy using everyday craft materials without blowing the poly budget.
key_stories.process: Tested cups, toilet rolls, textures; built low-poly thimble model, layered two-cycle shader for metallic bumps, hard-shaded edges.
key_stories.outcome: Final prototype accepted; will spawn around a Peach doodle and drop a Yoshi coin once coded.
key_stories.key_quote: I think this will look enough like a Shy Guy. Now he’s a nice bumpy little fella.

key_stories.title: Shader Identity Crisis
key_stories.summary: While faking shine on Styrofoam hills, Kaze realised his technique wasn’t a classic normal map but a camera-space specular hack. Debate with chat led to clarifying terms and confirming it works on moving lights and N64 constraints.
key_stories.challenge: Wanted dynamic shine on low-poly craft surfaces but unsure what mapping technique applied.
key_stories.process: Implemented per-pixel reflection using normal data, tested on hardware, discussed with viewers to label the method.
key_stories.outcome: Effect kept; vertex colours still to be added for depth.
key_stories.key_quote: Maybe people thought it wasn’t a normal map because every surface assumed the light came straight on, but the effect is what I need.
